threads.name: Anonymous
threads.com:
This board is dedicated to the discussion of history and the other humanities such as philosophy, religion, law, classical artwork, archeology, anthropology, ancient languages, etc. Please use /lit/ for discussions of literature. Threads should be about specific topics, and the creation of "general" threads is discouraged.

For the purpose of determining what is history, please do not start threads about events taking place less than 25 years ago. Historical discussions should be focused on past events, and not their contemporary consequences. Discussion of modern politics, current events, popular culture, or other non-historical topics should be posted elsewhere. General discussions about international culture should go on /int/.

/his/ is not /pol/, and Global Rule #3 is in effect. Do not try to treat this board as /pol/ with dates. Blatant racism and trolling will not be tolerated, and a high level of discourse is expected. History can be examined from many different conflicting viewpoints; please treat other posters with respect and address the content of their post instead of attacking their character.

When discussing history, please reference credible source material, and provide as much supporting information as possible in your posts.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
Not very long. Economic pressure would have forced them to abandon slavery probably within a generation anyway.

Let's say they win. They make most of their money exporting plantation crops, but don't have a lot of industry to process or refine what they produce, i.e. they produce lots of cotton, but don't have the means to turn it into fabric or cotton goods. Long term they could work on building up their domestic industry on that front, but they'd still be faced with a problem: their domestic demand for their own good is very low, because a third of their population is enslaved and doesn't consume the domestic product. So in order to make money they'd still be reliant on exports.

Now consider that everywhere else, slavery is being abolished left and right. Britain was initially sympathetic to the Confederacy only because of cheap cotton, but anti-slavery political pressure at home wouldn't allow them to openly back the Confederacy. Given how the tide of anti-slavery went in Europe, this sentiment would only grow stronger. Add on to this the fact Britain would eventually secure its own sources of cotton and other goods it bought from the Confederacy from its Asian colonies, and you have a recipe for the Confederacy being totally isolated from its wealthiest possible trade partners. It's economy would fall into a shambles.

The Confederacy would be put in a position where the United States and Britain would be able to exert political pressure to abolish slavery on them by holding trade deals for ransom.

That's because Homo erectus went extinct in Africa before the LCA of Neanderthals, Homo sapiens, and Denisovans even split into separate populations. The only regions where Homo erectus survived in at that time was in Europe and Asia, which is interesting because "Neandersovans" (the ancestors of both neanderthals and denisovans) have super-archaic ancestry that appears to be from Homo erectus that does not exist in modern humans. If West Africans (I'm using West Africans because there were two other archaic species of humans that interbred with hunter-gatherer populations in East, Central, and Southern Africa that did not mix with West Africans or proto-Eurasians) had any archaic human ancestry, it was likely Homo bodoensis/rhodesiensis or a potential sister species of Homo sapiens that lived in Africa that was somewhat closer to us than we are to Neanderthals. Homo bodoensis/rhodesiensis lived from around 700kya to as recently as 130kya, and was found in not only Africa but Southern Europe as well. They had a similar crainial size to modern humans, had flatter faces but significantly larger brow ridges than most species of humans, and was far more modern human-like in appearance than Homo erectus or Homo naledi. But unfortunately, this species doesn't fit the Robert Sepehr narrative that West Africans slept with ape-men.

Lithuanian has largely retained the Proto-Indo-European mobile accent, grammatical cases, and verbal conjugation system, which have been greatly altered in most other modern Indo-European languages. Of course there have been innovations as well, but Lithuanian is clearly more conservative than modern English, Hindi, Spanish, Greek, and so on. I've read that some early scholars thought that the Lithuanians must have been descended from Romans because the Lithuanian language has many similarities with Latin.

>Between these two, Vatavyadhi says that a calamity to the latter is

with money, troops and land in times of trouble.
>Kautilya disagrees. When one has an army, the ally continues to be friendly and [even] the enemy becomes a friend. However, when there is work that can be, done equally well by [his own] army and
[that of] the ally, the king should choose the appropriate instrument depending on the circumstances [the time, the place and the nature of
the action] and on whichever is more profitable. [But the king must remember that] no ally can be relied upon in cases of speedy expedition, internal rebellion or subduing jungle tribes. In case both the king
and the enemy suffer from calamities or when the enemy grows stronger, an ally [only] looks to his own interests [and maintains the alliance only if it is profitable to him.]
>The conqueror shall save from misfortune, one by one, the constituents of his state, in order of their importance; for, it is better that the ally remains in danger but not the army; likewise the army but not
the treasury. If the constituent as a whole can not be saved, at least parts shall be rescued; i.e., in the case of the army, the more numerous or the more loyal troops shall be saved leaving out the sharp and
the greedy; in the case of the treasury the most valuable or the most useful shall be saved;
The least important [constituents or parts of
constituents] shall be saved by peace, inactivity or a dual policy and the most important by other means [seeking help, preparing for or actually waging war.]

Trade and geographical position factor in too
If your ally is a great source of wealth for your people, and your enemy can not be bargained with, at least not as easily, or your ally is in a key strategic position, would it not be prudent to save your ally from calamity, even if it risks calamity falling on your army? >3. Commonwealth free trade zone. Britain could have made an EU style political-economic pact with her colonies to reduce trade barriers and improve the collaborative aspect of the commonwealth.
Sadly, Britain was lead by genuinely evil politicians following Churchill so none of this came to past. But my point is that this was BRITAIN'S FAULT, not just some foregone conclusion that Britain HAD to fail so spectacularly because of their debt to the US.

threads.name: Anonymous
threads.com:
Two thoughts on Catholicism, first on the indefectibility of the Church, and the second on transubstantiation.

>Mt. 16:18 ... on this rock I will build my church, and the gates of hell shall not prevail against it.

I'm not going to address the identity of the rock, but rather the latter part of the verse. This is taken to mean that the devil will never conquer the church, which is understood as the church defecting, or officially teaching false doctrine. This does not seem to be a natural reading of the text, however. To start with: what is a gate? A gate is a barrier of entrance, something that keeps things out (or in), essentially a defensive structure. The Catholic understanding of this verse rather construes this gate as something that is on the attack. But how does a gate attack? It makes more sense to understand the gate here as defensive, and the church as the offensive party, that the Church will overcome the gates of Hell. To give a modern analogy, one might say, "The fortifications at Normandy shall not prevail against the Allies." Of course Hell in this verse is the Greek term Hades, the underworld. The meaning is thus an assurance that the Church will conquer death. Death will not prevail against the body of Christ. So this isn't making any statement about indefectibility, but rather victory.

(1/2)

>At 15:23 on Sunday, May 31, 1970, the Ancash earthquake (also known as the Great Peruvian earthquake) struck off the coast of Peru with a moment magnitude of 7.9. The shaking dislodged a slab of rock about 800 m (2,600 ft) wide from the western face of Huascarán's north peak, at an elevation of roughly 5,600 to 6,200 m (18,400 to 20,300 ft).[17]:83 The rockfall occurred almost immediately after the shaking began, with witnesses comparing the sound to a gunshot or explosion.[5]:279 The fall triggered an "enormous dark cloud of dust" which rapidly blocked the view from below.[5]
>The rock fell some 600 m (2,000 ft) vertically[5]:302 before landing on Glacier 511 and sliding nearly 3 km (1.9 mi) down its surface, accumulating a large volume of firn snow as it went.[6] The initial ice-rock avalanche volume was at least 25 million m3 (33 million yd3), and grew rapidly in size as it fell down the steep Llanganuco valley, picking up large volumes of dirt, loose glacial moraine, water and uprooted trees. With area soils saturated near the end of the rainy season,[18] and the large amount of snow and ice scraped off the glacier surface,[5] the avalanche quickly liquefied into a fluid, fast-moving mudflow.[1]
>The maximum volume of mudflow was as much as 50-100 million m3 (130 million yd3),[19] and it reached speeds of up to 435 km/h (270 mph).[1] Some debris projectiles launched ahead of the main flow may have exceeded 1,100 km/h (680 mph).[5] According to a U.S. Geological Survey report published the same year, the mudflow may have achieved its unusually high speed due to "air-cushioned flow", a mixture of snow, ice and entrapped air that allowed the bulk of the material to essentially float over the ground.[1] The initial acceleration of the mass down the low-friction glacial surface was also a major factor, catapulting the material downhill at a much higher speed than if it had slid over bare rock or earth.[17]:84

It's interesting to me that proto-Indo-European theory is as old as 1647 at least, even if it didn't became mainstream at the time.

>In his 1647 essay,[8] Marcus Zuerius van Boxhorn proposed the existence of a primitive common language he called "Scythian". He included in its descendants Dutch, German, Latin, Greek, and Persian, and his posthumously published Originum Gallicarum liber[9] of 1654 added Slavic, Celtic and Baltic.[10] The 1647 essay discusses, as a first, the methodological issues in assigning languages to genetic groups. For example, he observed that loanwords should be eliminated in comparative studies, and also correctly put great emphasis on common morphological systems and irregularity as indicators of relationship.[11] A few years earlier, the Silesian physician Johann Elichmann (1601/1602–1639) already used the expression ex eadem origine (from a common source) in a study published posthumously in 1640.[12] He related European languages to Indo-Iranian languages (which include Sanskrit).[11]

>The idea that the first language was Hebrew continued to be advanced for some time: Pierre Besnier (1648–1705) in 1674 published a book which was translated into English the following year: A philosophical essay for the reunion of the languages, or, the art of knowing all by the mastery of one.[13]

>In the post-classical West, with the influence of Christianity[citation needed], language studies were undermined by the naïve attempt to derive all languages from Hebrew since the time of Saint Augustine. He identified Greek, Germanic, Romance and Slavic language groups by comparing the word for "God" in various European languages. In 1710, Leibniz applied ideas of gradualism and uniformitarianism to linguistics in a short essay.[2] Like Scaliger, he rejected a Hebrew root, but also rejected the idea of unrelated language groups and considered them all to have a common source.[3]
